We swept a four game series with Kingston, back to back doubleheaders with Winston-Salem, and kicked the holy shit out of Greensboro in a three game series... They were in demand all over town -- and Crash, who kept hitting dingers, was approaching the minor league record... though I told nobody. question: Why baseball?
answer: I was raised in a Baptist church got dipped in the water when I was 5 -- born again before kindergarten... by the time I was 10 I knew it was bullshit and at 15 I ran away from home... pregnant, had an abortion, got pregnant again, had an abortion again... gave up men. Tried women. Missed men. My mother died. I bought a car for $200 and drove to Ft. Lauderdale to bury her. And after we'd sung some hymns in some wretched Florida funeral home, I went outside and something happened -- The smell of cut grass in the warm March air overwhelmed me and I heard a noise -- ) -- tok, tok, tok -- and some men shouting... then tok, tok, tok. I crossed the street -- it was the New York Yankees spring training field -- tok, tok, tok, was the sound of a ball hitting a bat -- and I sat in the warm bleachers to think about my mother... And I saw him.

question: Who?
answer: Thurman Munson. He was covered with dirt and he was fighting with everybody -- it was beautiful... And he called the ump a cocksucker and got thrown out of the game even though it was an exhibition! So I stayed in the bleachers all spring and gradually came to understand what's so great about baseball.

question: What's so great about baseball?
answer: If you know where home plate is, then you know where 1st base is, and 2nd, and everything else -- 'cause they're always in the same place in relation to home. Don't you see? If you know where home plate is, then you know where everything else in the universe is!

question: Uh oh... Can I offer you some coffee?
answer: Yeah... Ebby tells me you're a very spiritual woman. He tells me you've taught him a lot about discipline and self-control.

question: He's a good student.
answer: We were worried that Ebby might get involved with the wrong crowd in professional baseball -- we're so pleased, he met a Christian woman.

question: Praise the Lord, eh? Oh my -- I better fix that. Ebby will you help me? I'm no good with mechanical things
answer: I couldn't dump my old man but maybe later I can sneak away from him...

question: You don't have to...
answer: I'm starting to understand what you're teaching me. I mean the panties and the nostrils and all that shit... I mean I'm getting it --

question: So am I. Nuke, honey, we need to talk --
answer: Aw hell, let's have a quickie right here --

question: -- but you're father's in there!
answer: Crash says I gotta quit worrying about him -- c'mon, honey, we got a lotta catching up to do --

question: Nuke -- we do need to talk! Hello? Skip? Yeah, as a matter of fact, he is here. It's Skip, for you.
answer: Yeah, Skip, it's me. Jeez... Jeez... God... Jeez... I'm going to the Show. They're sending me up to finish out the season with the Big Club. I'm going to the Show!

question: Oh let's not...
answer: I gotta leave first thing in the morning.

question: That's great!
answer: How can I possibly thank you?

question: Just pitch well and do good.
answer: I will, I will -- C'mon, Dad, I'll dump you off. I gotta find Crash.

question: Crash ain't there. He never gets back till four or five --
answer: Where does he go?

question: Well, I'd rather not say.
answer: They called me up to the Show and I wanta tell Crash goodbye.

question: Goddamn, that's great! Jesus! Listen, Crash don't like anybody to know it but -- Most nights he goes down to, you know, down to Niggertown. To Sandy's... the whorehouse.
answer: He goes to a whorehouse every night?

question: What'you want, kid?
answer: I'm looking for somebody.

question: Who ain't?
answer: Looking for Crash Davis.

question: Ain't here.
answer: I'm Nuke LaLoosh. With the Bulls.

question: But when she does get weary -- Try a little tenderness... You know she's waiting, just anticipating, the things that she'll never possess... While she's there waiting -- Try a little tenderness...
answer: Crash. I'm going to the Show. Club's expanding its roster to finish the season --

question: Shut up. I'm playing. Oh you won't regret it, young girls don't forget it, lost in their own wilderness... But it's all so easy -- Just try a little tenderness...
answer: I'm going to the Show.

question: Then go.
answer: I'm trying to thank you.

question: Let go of me!
answer: He makin' trouble for you, Mr. Davis?

question: No, no, Sandy, put it down. Nuke, you know Sandy Grimes? Hit .367 at Louisville in 155.
answer: I hit .371.

question: He hit .371 -- C'mon, Nuke -- you and me, let's step outside and settle this.
answer: Settle what?

question: C'mon!
answer: I don't wanta fight you, I wanta thank you. Let's have a drink and forget this --

question: God damn it, you fucking virgin prick -- step outside.
answer: C'mon, we got nothin' to fight about.

question: You fuck!
answer: Why am I a fuck?

question: Why are you a fuck? 'Cause you got talent. I got brains. But you got talent! You're God damn left arm is worth a million dollars a year. All my limbs put together are worth 7 cents a pound -- and that's for science and dog meat.
answer: You're a great catcher.

question: Come over here into the light so I can kick your ass.
answer: No.

question: Okay, I'll kick your ass there. ...God damn... I forgot my fucking shoes. Honey, go get my shoes.
answer: I'll take you back to the hotel.

question: You know what the difference is between hitting .250 and hitting .300? I got it figured out. Twenty-five hits a year in 500 at bats is 50 points. Okay? There's 6 months in a season, that's about 25 weeks -- you get one extra flare a week -- just one -- a gork, a ground ball with eyes, a dying quail -- just one more dying quail a week and you're in Yankee Stadium!
answer: Forget it. You ain't worth thanking --

question: Come on, Meat... Nuke... tell me something. Did you hit me with your right or your left?
answer: My right.

question: Good. Good. That's terrific...
answer: What?

question: If ya get in a fight with some asshole, never hit his with your pitching hand. Ya might get injured. That's another lesson for ya -- now quit fucking around and help me up.
answer: Ya look like shit.

question: Sorry about last night.
answer: Forget it.

question: I have been known, on occasion, to howl at the moon. D'you understand that?
answer: No.

question: You will. Look, Nuke -- these Big League hitters are gonna light you up like a pin ball machine for awhile -- don't worry about it. Be cocky and arrogant even when you're getting beat. That's the secret. You gotta play this game with fear and arrogance.
answer: Fear and ignorance.

question: No. Fear and arrogance, you, hayseed, not ignorance!
answer: I know. I just like to see you get all worked up. Well, I got Annie all warmed up for ya... She's just waiting for you to show up, y'know...

question: I don't need a crazy woman in my life.
answer: Maybe you do. Y'know I'm starting to like this game -- baseball's a helluva good way to make a living.

question: It's the best, Nuke... the absolute fucking best.
answer: Yeah, thanks for everything.

question: Nuke -- Good luck.
answer: You too... Meat.

question: You too... Meat.
answer: Well I guess this is it.

question: I won't be needing these anymore.
answer: Neither will I.

question: I think I'm ready for the Show.
answer: Ebby Calvin Nuke LaLoosh -- don't think too much.

question: I got released.
answer: I heard already. Oh my... ...so you see in a former lifetime I'm sure that I was Alexandria, the Czarette of Russia? What do you think?

question: How come in former lifetimes, everybody was someone famous? How come nobody ever says they were Joe Schmo?
answer: It doesn't work like that. God, you're gorgeous. Want to dance? ...mouth, tongue, lips, teeth, roof of the mouth, jaws, and the jaw hinges...

question: ...wrist and wrist joints, hand, palm, knuckles, thumb, fore-finger, finger-joints, finger-nail...
answer: Crash said he had to get an early start to drive to Asheville in the South Atlantic League where he heard they might need a catcher to finish out the season... The house smelled like sex for days. It was wonderful. The only real cleaning I did was on the kitchen floor 'cause who likes to walk on spilt cereal? The funny thing is, I stopped worrying about Nuke. Somehow I knew nothing would stop him. Crash was right -- Nuke had a gift.
